issues.description: The problem statement / UML specifies orderMeal(Meal): void (a void method) but the solution implementation declares orderMeal as returning boolean (public boolean orderMeal(Meal)). This return-type mismatch contradicts the specification and will confuse students about the expected signature and behavior (tests or grader may expect a void method).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method signature consistent with the problem statement. Either (A) change the solution (and template) orderMeal signature to public void orderMeal(Meal meal) and keep the same behavior (add to orders, adjust totalOrders, call checkOrderReady()), or (B) update the problem statement and UML to indicate that orderMeal returns boolean and explain the meaning of the returned value. Prefer option A to match the given UML/spec (void).

issues.description: The problem text instructs students to initialize both attributes (orders and stock) in the SealSaloon constructor ("These should be initialized to default values ... in the constructor"), but elsewhere the statement requires the stock attribute to be static/shared across instances. Initializing a static field in the instance constructor conflicts with the static requirement and is ambiguous: should stock be an instance final field initialized in the constructor or a static field initialized elsewhere? The solution implements stock as a static final field initialized at declaration (private static final Stock stock = new Stock()).
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the intended ownership and initialization of stock in the problem statement. Either: (A) Keep the requirement that stock is shared/static and instruct students to initialize it as a static field (e.g., initialize at declaration or in a static initializer) and only initialize orders in the instance constructor; or (B) if stock should be an instance final field, remove the note requiring it to be static and keep the instruction to initialize it in the constructor. Update the UML/description to consistently reflect the chosen design.
